Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation2: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Story: I was on my way out to meet my friends for dinner when I saw my younger sister waiting by the elevator, her face lighting up as she spotted me. “Hey, are you going out? Can I come?” she asked, hopeful. I hesitated, remembering how we’d promised to include each other more, to build that mutual respect we’d sometimes let slip. But just as I was about to answer, Mrs. Patel from down the hall approached, her lips pressed in a thin line. “Excuse me, could I have a word?” she said, glancing at my sister and then back at me. I knew immediately what it was about—the noise complaint that had been circulating. As a neighbor, I was expected to be friendly and polite, especially now, face-to-face in the lobby. I felt my stomach twist. My sister looked at me, waiting for my answer, while Mrs. Patel waited for my attention. I could feel the weight of both roles pressing on me, each demanding something different, and I stood there, caught between the expectations of being a good sister and a considerate neighbor, unsure which way to turn.
